entry.title: Show 8: Mental Illness with Greg Baugues and Ed Finkler
entry.content:
A slightly-lengtier-than-usual discussion about how mental health intersects with the developer community.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe, GitHub issue.

Topics Covered:

  • Our histories
  • How do we know if we’re unwell?
  • How can I help someone who is suffering?
  • How do I talk to my employer/team/clients about my health?
  • How do I manage my illness long term?
  • What are some common management strategies?

Panelists:

  • Alex Gibson
  • Ed Finkler
  • Greg Baugues
  • James Harton
  • Merrin Macleod

Resources:

  • devpressed.com – discourse forum for depression in tech
  • Blue Hackers – articles and information specific for technologists
  • > Prompt – mental health awareness event
  • The Mental Illness Happy Hour – podcast (and forum) about mental illness
  • Stanford’s Sapolsky On Depression in U.S. (Full Lecture)
  • United States specific mental health resources:
    • Mental Health First Aid
    • Mental Health America
  • New Zealand specific mental health resources:
    • Wellington Mental Health Services (crisis number)
    • Palmerston North Mental Health Services (crisis number)
    • Auckland Mental Health Services
    • Christchurch Mental Health Services
    • Working Well
    • Mental Health Foundation of NZ

entry.title: Show 7: RSpec 3 with Jon Rowe
entry.content:
A discussion about the upcoming RSpec 3 release with Jon Rowe, a member of the RSpec core team.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Topics covered:

  • What is RSpec
  • Why RSpec (instead of minitest, for example)
  • Differences between RSpec 2.x and 3
  • When will RSpec 3 be released?

Panelists:

  • James Harton
  • Philip Arndt
  • Samson Ootoovak
  • Shevaun Coker
  • Ryan Bigg

entry.title: Show 6: Teaching Ruby
entry.content:
Panel discussion about teaching Ruby with Eoin Kelly, Joshua Vial and Mathew Hartley.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Topics covered:

  • I want to learn Ruby
  • Ruby’s Tea Party
  • Dev Academy
  • Learning at University vs Technical Training vs on-the-job or self-taught.
  • Difficultly level in starting out. Is Rails too big for beginners?
  • Not everyone is learning to be a professional developer.
  • Self-directed vs curriculum.
  • Getting beginners along to meetups.
  • Apprenticeships.
  • Pairing, mentoring and demonstration.

Panelists:

  • Amanda Wagener
  • James Harton
  • Philip Arndt
  • Samson Ootoovak

entry.title: Show 5: Ruby Community with Nahum Wild
entry.content:
Interview with Nahum Wild about Wellington’s wellrailed user group, and organising Rails Camp.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Topics covered:

  • Fostering different skill levels
  • Finding time to organise events
  • Diversity and providing a safe environment
  • Beer (and other refreshments)
  • Why is the ruby community so great?

Panelists

  • James Harton
  • Pat Allen
  • Philip Arndt
  • Samson Ootovak

entry.title: Show 4: Ruby 2.1
entry.content:
A panel discussion about the imminent Ruby 2.1 Release and the changes likely to be included.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Topics covered:

  • Refinements
  • Call site method caching
  • Generational garbage collector How to make Perfume dance
  • Frozen string literals
  • Method definition returns method name
  • Decimal literals
  • StringScanner uses named captures
  • Required keyword arguments
  • Updated RubyGems

Panelists

  • Henry Maddocks
  • James Harton
  • Samson Ootoovak
  • Shevaun Coker
  • Tim Carey-Smith

entry.title: Show 3: Capistrano with Lee Hambley
entry.content:
An interview with Lee Hambley (github, twitter) about Capistrano, it’s current status and maintainership.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Interview questions:

  • What got you interested in Capistrano in the first place?
  • How did you become the maintainer of Capistrano?
  • Can you summarise your recent public statement?
  • What did it feel like to have to admit that it was all too much?
  • What was the response to your public statement?
  • How are you feeling about it today?
  • Will you consider maintaining large open source projects in future?
  • How has maintaining a large open source project impacted your usage of other large projects?
  • What advice do you have to reduce the likelihood of other project maintainers reaching the same point of burnout?
  • What things can contributors or users of open source do to help maintainers?

Panelists:

  • Amanda Wagener
  • Henry Maddocks
  • James Harton
  • Philip Arndt
  • Tim Carey-Smith

entry.title: Show 2: A globally distributed team
entry.content:
An interview with Andrew Hooker (github, twitter) and Ryan Bigg (github, twitter) of Spree Commerce, where we discuss the implications of working inside of a globally distributed team, and on a set of products which comprise a large open source component.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Topics covered:

  • How Spree is coordinated and features are decided
  • Sprint planning across time zones
  • GitHub workflow
  • Spree team structure
  • How teams work across great distances

Panelists:

  • Amanda Wagener
  • Henry Maddocks
  • James Harton
  • Philip Arndt
  • Tim Carey-Smith

entry.title: Show 1: Intro to "do"
entry.content:
Who are these people? Why should I listen to them? Can they diverge onto massive tangents for many minutes at a time? Download MP3.

To find out the answer to all these questions and more, listen to our first ever show. Available for your downloading pleasure here or you can subscribe to our RSS feed in your favourite podcatcher.

entry.title: do: A podcast about Ruby and Rubyists
entry.content:
“do” is a podcast about Ruby, Rubyists and their culture. We hope to grow to be a regular (at this stage, two-weekly) show, with a rotating panel of up to 10 people.

Get involved.

The show schedule is managed in our GitHub issues, ideas for future shows can also be raised as issues for discussion, and may wind up being assigned to the schedule (issue milestones) for future recording.

Here’s how you can get involved:

  • If you’d like to be on a panel, add yourself to the panel list of an upcoming show. no more than 5 panelists, plus guest per show please!

  • If you’d like to be present at the recording of one of our episodes? Just follow us on Google+ and we’ll post events for our upcoming hangouts-on-air.

  • Make show or interview suggestions by raising or commenting on our GitHub issues.
